desc:
**PLEASE NOTE THAT WE'RE MEETING AT OPEN SOURCE COWORKING THIS MONTH AND NOT BUFFALO BILLIARD'S!**

Securing Applications Without Compromising User Experience


Software is typically developed with the end user in mind. As software developers, we go to great lengths to ensure that users can have a seamless experience. However, allowing users to conveniently access their application allows attackers the opportunity to attack users with just as much ease. The eternal struggle that designers and developers face is striking a balance in design and security in order to not compromise the user but optimize his/her satisfaction. This talk will explore some practical strategies that can be implemented in order to improve the security posture of most applications without compromising on the user experience.

Speaker bio: David Vo is a senior consultant with nVisium’s Application Consulting practice. His specialties include application pen-test, source code reviews, and vulnerability analysis, including using fuzzing to find software vulnerabilities. He is also an expert in mobile security, including the Apple iOS and Android platforms.

The State of Refresh

Every year at the beginning of the year, we take a moment to do a "retro" of sorts and ask you — our community — what worked, what didn't, and what we can improve upon for Refresh Austin in the new year. Come give us your feedback, and let us know what topics you want to hear about in the new year!

------------------------------------------------------------------

desc:
Bots on bots on botkit

(Michael Way, Developer)

The rise of the chat bots is upon us. There's a new tool to help making chat bots as simple as possible. Botkit is a node based open source project for all you need for a chat bot and possibly beyond. This is an introduction to botkit and what may be in store for the next generation of applications.


Getting to 90,000 ft and back again in 1-piece

(Tom Dickman, Shaun Dubuque, Developers, RetailMeNot)

Ever wonder what the weather is like at 90,000 ft or itching for a good use for that new GoPro camera? Perfect, join Tom Dickman and Shaun Dubuque, both from RetailMeNot's Innovation group, as they discuss the do's and don'ts of launching a payload into the far reaches of the atmosphere. This talk with touch on everything from atmospheric sensors, GPS tracking at high altitudes, launch timing/planning, and the building of custom tracking software so you can track your balloon in real-time and improve your chances of a successful recovery.

It's back: Your favorite SXSW party with no free drinks, no mandatory RSVPs, and no badge required! That's right, it's our eighth annual pre-SXSW lunch at B.D. Riley's. 

Drop in for a pint. Or stay for a bite, and hang out for a while. 

Everyone is welcome. This is a casual come-and-go-as-you-please lunchtime event. Some appetizers will be provided for the group, but you’ll need to pick up your own tab--or even buy a round for your new friends.

Note that this meetup is during the day--and not on our typical second Tuesday. We'll be back to our regularly scheduled programming in April.

PLEASE RSVP ON TICKETBUD -->https://austinonrails.ticketbud.com/sxsw-web-developer-happy-hour-2016-d34639587df6

You're invited to the once a year extravaganza that is the... SXSW WEB DEVELOPER HAPPY HOUR!

Please join us on the Monday of SXSW for good conversation, appetizers, and a night out without the laptop. Buffalo Billiards has tons of games, such as darts, billiards, and shuffleboard. 

We invited bonafide web geek and designer Alex Baldwin to DJ our event. It's easily the best party for the HTTP set. 

Web developers of all stripes are welcome!
name: [Cross-post] SXSW Web Developer Happy Hour 2016

desc:
Did you notice something special this month? Yes, we had SXSW descend upon Austin, but more importantly we have five whole Tuesdays! Let's celebrate by grabbing a pint at The Ginger Man and catching up with some of your favorite people. There's tons to chat about: your favorite SXSW panels or anti-SXSW activities; how do you and your company deal with central points of failure in your software build; what's your favorite strategy for dealing with your allergies. The topics are endless!

New to Austin or haven't heard of a #BeerSummit? They started as a friendly way to avoid the never ending rabbit hole of Twitter discussions. After three or four replies back and forth on the same subject, someone could propose a #BeerSummit and all discussion had to stop. You couldn't start back up again until everyone had a pint (ale, beer, root beer, water, didn't matter) in their hands sitting around the same table. They've evolved into a simple way to gather the community to talk tech without a schedule.

Swing by for as long as you'd like and buy pint for a friend old or new!
name: 5th Tuesday #BeerSummit!

desc:
Copywriting with Git
Michael Neal, UI / UX Designer (@iammichaelneal)

Attention copywriters and creative writers! Do you find yourself roaming from platform to platform, purchasing app after app, in search for the perfect distraction free writing environment that also accommodates your revision workflow, supporting experimental drafts and multiple collaborators? Why not build your own? Come see what the buzz is all about at this refresh talk, we'll lightly cover what it is like to use the free tools that developers use everyday and how you can use these tools to create your own personalized, distributable, distraction-free, writing environment for free.


Life after bootcamp: fighting stigma, and continuing your education.

Last year, we talked to fresh-off-the-boat bootcamp grads as they started their career in tech. We thought we'd do a follow-up, and talk to other bootcamp grads who have been out of the bootcamp for a much longer time, or are even in their second job after bootcamp. How are they navigating their tech careers, do they face any stigma for being a bootcamp grad, and how to they keep their skills sharp?

HUGE thanks to our sponsor thins month, Hired!

desc:
We’re All Impostors. Probably. 


Casey Hunt (@caseymhunt)

Impostor Complex: not officially recognized as a psychological disorder yet experienced by nearly everyone. As a Hybrid, I am a little bit of everything and therefore am none of those things. I’ve been an impostor all my life, literally living the mantra, “fake it ’til you make it.” Me, you, a half hour and some uncomfortable honesty. Let’s be impostors together and maybe, just maybe, I’ll help you figure out how to deal. ❤️

Digital Security and Privacy for Non-Hackers. 
Dan DeFelippi (@ExpertDan)

As geeks we're expected to know everything about protecting ourselves in a hostile online environment. Data breeches are on the rise and media hype makes it sound like everyone is out to get you. Unless you work in computer security it's hard to know the facts. This talk outlines the actual risks and simple steps you can take to protect yourself. 

HUGE thanks to our sponsor this month, Dev Bootcamp!

desc:
Style Guide-Driven Development:  The perfect marriage of design and development

Adriana De La Cuadra

Design and development silos are very common on many projects impairing implementation and creating unhappiness among the team. Style Guide Driven Development proposes to marry these two concepts to create a happier relationship by using a Live Style Guide that both designers and developers can use to not only document but also do their work! Learn how to incorporate this approach into your development workflow and on the way how you can use the open source tool DocumentCSS to create Live Style Guides and multi-version documentation.


Custom Properties in CSS - the What and the How


Derek Gulledge

Custom properties are a fairly new technology in CSS and can be utilized in interesting ways. This talk will explain what they are how you can use them.


HUGE thanks to our sponsor this month, Condé Nast!

desc:
BLURRED LINES 
Kyle Fiedler (@kylefiedler)

Should designers code? Should they generalize or specialize? As a community we constantly reiterate these same arguments. What makes a great team is when each member’s lines of responsibility blurs into that of others. At thoughtbot, designers have a wide range of responsibilities from business strategy to graphic design, to implementing a great user experience in the app. Kyle discusses why this has been successful for their teams and how designer and developer lines blur together at thoughtbot.

HACKATHONING A SALARY
Hannah Oppenheimer (@opihana)

Get rich quick! Or not. Either way, participating in a hackathon can be a rewarding (and weird) experience. I was lucky enough to win a few hackathons, earn $60,000 doing it, and even got a real job out of it. I’ll tell you what my teams did well, what we failed miserably on, and how it actually helped us become better developers and designers in a startup environment.

HUGE thanks to our sponsor this month, Keep Ruby Weird!

desc:
VOICE ON THE WEB
Matt Buck (@techpeace)

With the introduction of voice assistants like Siri and Google Now, and more recently, ubiquitous voice interfaces like the Amazon Echo, voice is in the midst of a renaissance. Matt Buck, co-founder of conversational interface agency Voxable, will explain the importance of voice interfaces, review the fundamentals of conversational design, and demonstrate how to make use of the Web Speech API today. Learn how to turn your users into wizards via the magic of voice.

EVALUATING JOB OFFERS 101
Brian Showers

Brian will help you understand how to do an apples-to-apples comparison of offer compensation, including salary, bonus, and equity.

HUGE thanks to our sponsor this month, data.world!

We're taking a break from our normally scheduled programming on Election Day, and we want to encourage you to GO VOTE. We don't care who you vote for, so long as you do!

While we're on the subject of the polls, we have a short survey for you to take while you're waiting in line to cast your vote. 

If the line is even longer than our quick poll, then take the time to mark your calendars for two dates: 

• November 29: Fifth Tuesday; We'll have a Beer Summit at a location to be announced. Stay tuned.

• December 13: The Austin Web Bash, or #AWBASH, holiday party is back! Every year, Refresh Austin hosts the  to bring Austin's web and tech meetups together under one roof to celebrate the end of the year. If you help run a meetup that you want to participate or you're with a company that wants to sponsor, then let us know.

desc:
You’re in a conflict with your teammates. User growth has stalled out. You can’t get an investor to commit. 

It doesn’t matter how amazing your team is, how many resources you have, or how well you understand your customers: eventually, every venture gets stuck. The question is, what do you do to get unstuck?


In this interactive workshop, you will:
- Share the challenges you’re facing and identify your biggest bottleneck. 
- Learn how to build an army of people who want to help you. 
- Make it easy for others (customers, partners, advisors) to help solve your biggest challenges. 

Trevor Boehm is a Venture Fellow at UnLtd USA, which invests and supports entrepreneurs who are tackling our most pressing problems. He coaches teams on early-stage growth, business modeling, and user experience design. Trevor led the launch of Get Backed, a bestselling book on startup fundraising, has designed programs at the Acton School of Business, and was the founder of the e-commerce startup Penny.

 ** This is a different format than the regular monthly meetup so space will be limited to 60 people. It will have many group exercises & run two hours **


Space provided by Capital Factory. Light drinks & snacks provided.


Agenda:
 =====  
6:30-6:45pm Sign-in and socializing  
6:45-7:00pm Announcements, General discussion    
7:00-9:00pm "Getting Unstuck" by Trevor Boehm
9:00- ?pm Buffalo Billiards (Brazos and 6th).
name: Feb: Getting Unstuck - Solving Pressing Problems & Moving Your Venture Forward

desc: We're hosting a rather last minute get-together at Easy Tiger tomorrow. Stop by if you're in the area, grab a drink, and meet other LEAN enthusiasts from all over. We are restricted on space so please RSVP only if you can attend. (You don't need a SXSW badge)
name: SXSW Social

desc:
Successful fundraising is hard. 

Every entrepreneur believes their idea deserves funding yet the process often feels like a big catch-22... no investor wants to jump in unless others have already given funds or the numbers are a no-brainer.

Investors don't give out money easily so what does it take? 

Join us for an interactive Q&A with Tony Aguilar, Founder and CEO of Student Loan Genius, on his recent experience getting 3 million in seed funding. 


• Building a compelling pitch and the path to honing it

• Getting investors to help you, even if you get a "no"

• Framing talks with angel investors versus institutional VCs 

• Generating investor momentum to close your round

This is going to be less presentation and more of an honest talk so come on out with you questions!


~~ Emiliano Villarreal

Tony Aguilar is a former professional poker player turned CEO of Austin-based Student Loan Genius - the 401k for student loans. 

Investors in SLG include Gibraltar Ventures (an affiliate of Prudential), John Hancock/Manulife, Kapor Capital, Socratic Ventures, Capital Factory, and Village Capital.

---


Space provided by Capital Factory. Light drinks & snacks provided. 

Agenda: 
 =====  
6:30-6:45pm Sign-in and socializing  
6:45-7:00pm Announcements, General discussion    
7:00-8:00pm "Fundraising Insights Straight from the Trenches " by Tony Aguilar of Student Loan Genius 
8:00- ?pm Buffalo Billiards (Brazos and 6th).
name: "Fundraising Insights Straight from the Trenches" by Tony Aguilar

desc:
For the last several months the "Press-o-Shere" has been filled with news about the critical importance of the WordPress JSON REST API to the future of the platform. 

During this past year, the JSON REST API has been a frequent topic of discussion at the Advanced WordPress Dev meet-ups. Nick Batik thought to use our first Deep Dive Discussion of 2016 to focus the conversation on getting our WPATX practitioners and endusers familiar with the concepts of the JASON REST APIs. 

This will be an informal discussion of concepts you need to understand in order to take  advantage of the possibilities full adoption of the REST API will open up to our community of users. This conversation will not be a technical "HOW-TO." Our purpose is to introduce the REST API to those who unfamiliar with the topic, and help them prepare for a more technical understanding of the subject.

The WPATX Organizers are planning a Technical Panel Discussion of the WORDPRESS JASON REST API for our WordPress Practitioners Meetup March 22. Our Build a Sign venue can hold up to 80 attendees and we expect that it will be a full house. That meet-up will be more a "HOW-TO" and will refer members to a number of online resources for follow up. Nick will post the notes about his JASON REST API conversation for those who can make this month's DDD.
name: A Conversation About the WordPress JSON REST API

desc:
The first WordPress for Beginners meet-up will start with questions, hopefully lots and lots of questions. 


Your organizers are opening the floor for our Annual Community Q&A Session. 

You all have been working on your sites since our November meet-up. 

Have you run across an issue or a problem that has you stumped, stuck, confused or just plain annoyed:

A glich in your Google Analytics?

The WordPress 4.4 upgrade?

Where to start with Maintenance/ Security/ Backups?

Plugin Paralysis?

Navigation Nausea

Chaos with your Child Theme?

Bring your issues, questions, and your laptop. 

Your WordPress Beginners Support Team, Nick Batik, Rich Plakas and Sandi Batik will answer what we can and find resources for what we can't.

We will close our evening asking you some questions. 

We need to know what topics you want us to present in the 2016 Beginners Sessions.

Would you like us to schedule more "Site Show and Tells?" 

Would you like to have another site critique night?

The WPATX Beginner's session topics have always been member driven  — so you need to let your Support Team know what you would find most helpful.

You can post questions and comments on this meet-up page or use @WPATX and we can read them from the @WPATX Twitter feed.

Looking forward to seeing you at a WPATX meet-up soon.
name: WordPress Beginners Annual Q&A Session

desc:
Welcome to the first WPATX topic-driven, WordPress Practitioner meetup of 2016 — Best Practices for Marketing and Social Media.  We are so pleased to once again, have Social Media and Marketing professional, Ricardo Guerrero present to our group.

You've learned some WordPress. You've created & optimized your site. (OH? You haven't?) You've built it. Now, how do you get folks to come?

Ricardo will focus this meetup on some best practices for marketing and social media, with a side of optimization using a few tools to help ensure your baby has a good user experience, particularly Google Analytics, CrazyEgg & FengGui. 

Once we see how well you've done making your site usable, we'll move on to easy tactics for fleshing out a consistent social media presence for yourself or your clients (using Buffer via this link: http://bit.ly/RGbuffer) as well as some social listening platforms (free: Hootsuite.com & paid: Mention.com). We'll wrap up with a look at how advertising works on Facebook and potentially Instagram & Twitter if there's time. Of course, your questions will lead the conversation as well.

Note: this will be a live demo of tools and processes, not a slide presentation.

Ricardo Guerrero is currently the Digital Marketing Director at TDECU.org  - He is a collaborative digital and social strategy marketing leader, who has provided experienced leadership and strategy to all areas of Digital Marketing including Online Demand Generation, e-Commerce (conversion improvement), Social Media, Content Marketing, Web Analytics, SEO/SEM, eMail andMobile projects. Ricardo's past WPATX presentations  have always been thoughtful and action provoking. Get there early and be ready to learn from one of the best. You can follow Ricardo at: @ggroovin and  linkedin.com/in/RicardoGuerrero.

We look forward to seeing you there. Bring your questions and your laptop. The seating at Build-a-Sign can difficult if you are very tall or have a tricky back, so when in doubt, bring a camp chair for your comfort.
name: Best Practices for Marketing and Social Media

desc:
Toyin Akinmusuru, of HubAustin CoWorking is again hosting WordPress Office hours. WordPress Organizers and volunteers are on hand to answer WordPress Questions and help you with specific problems that may be holding you back from your next step.

You are welcome to just come in set up your computer, work on your WordPress project and check out the HubCoworking space. 

If you are a little further along in your WordPress Journey, please feel free to drop by and help someone else who is just learning. The more WPATX volunteers we have on hand the faster we can help our WP Office hour attendees get over the hump that has them stuck.

We really need UX /UI 'Front-end volunteers as most of the questions these past few months have been centered on " My theme won't....!" 

Thanks and we look forward to seeing you there! 

Right now we are limiting Office Hours to 10 attendees. If we get more WordHead Volunteers we will increase attendee number. Thx - Sandi
name: WordPress Office Hours

desc:
THERE WILL BE NO JAN 2016  WP ADVANCED DEV MEETUP! 

Our first 2016 WP ADV Dev Meetup will be Kicked off on Feb 2 by Zach Rothauser sharing some code and processes. 

In this focused front-end engineering session, we'll look at the new possibilities in web design using some of the newer CSS features. We’ll begin by taking a look how some basic layouts can immediately be improved with the new CSS grids, columns, and flexbox. We’ll then move on to using some of the more advanced features of flexbox to solve real world challenges.


This will be an Advance WordPress Developer Level Presentation. Our great sponsor WP Engine will provide munchies and soft drinks.
name: Zack Rothauser: Modern CSS with Flexbox, Grids, and Columns

desc:
Sandi Batik will lead this month's Deep Dive Discussion which will focus on what it takes to build a successful freelance WordPress business. The WPATX organizers have had numerous requests to devote more meetups to the "Business" of WordPress.  If this discussion topic proves popular, we will expand the topic into a more formal class for our WordPress Practitioners meetup, which is hosted in a larger venue.


Please come prepared to talk about the tools and techniques you currently use in the everyday course of your business. Topics will include prospecting, marketing, proposal writing, client interviews and on boarding, project management, client management, project close-out and invoicing client follow-up and what ever else you might want to address in the time we have.

HubAustin can comfortably manage about 25 folks. We have had a on-going problem with members who are committing to go, changing their minds, but not their RSVP on this page. This has resulted in folks on the waiting list missing a discussion they really wanted to attend. This year, we will take attendance for every meeting that has a wait list. 

If two times in a 12 month period, someone who has committed to attend, but is a No-SHOW who has not changed their RSVP to open their spot; that person will be considered a probable no-show and their spot automatically opened for the next person in line. 

Tracking this means extra work for the WPATX organizers, which I personally am not happy about, but we have had so many complaints from other members who are missing a class unnecessarily, that we have to do something. I am open to any non-lethal options - I  did mention that we are getting a lot of member complaints right. ;-) 

Please be considerate and lets make our small-group discussions fun, not a bone to be fought over.  Thanks so much for your undersatnading and cooperation - Sandi
name: The WordPress Freelancer's Tool Box

desc:
Rich Plakas will lead this session designed to support those new to WordPress. Good photos, logos, icons and other images on a site are key to a website's appeal, popularity and conversion rates. We will review uploading images in pages and posts, including the media settings, size options, as well as default image sizes – resizing images, creating thumbnails and the value of the alt tag and captions for SEO. 

The presentation will also demonstrate how to use the WordPress built-in image alignment features and help attendees understand how images interact with the text; and will include wrapping text around images, changing margins, padding and borders around the images within the content and when and how to use the ‘Featured Image’ option. Photoblogs and Galleries will also be discussed, as well as some of the best plugins to use to manage and/or display images. We will close with a Q&A. Bring your laptops and your questions! 

This class was first presented in 2013 and has been updated and being repeated based on membership requests. 

Reminder: This is a class designed for those new to WordPress. We will not be discussing advanced image handling techniques. If you have advanced questions please save them for the Q&A at the next general WordPress Meetup.
name: Understanding the Basics of WordPress Media Library

desc:
Automattic and Google are teaming up with theAustin Gay & Lesbian Chamber of Commerce on February 18, 2016. The event will help give Texan LGBT businesses and nonprofits the tools to accelerate their organizations.

The event will offer 5 hours of educational content to help grow your organization

Location: Google AUS MOP, 9606 N Mopac Expy #100, Austin, TX 78759

desc:
...and what it might mean for you

WordPress first evolved from a lean blogging tool to a full fledged CMS. This year WordPress  starts moving towards its next  transformation. The REST API will unlock new possibilities for everyone in the WordPress Community, from end users, practitioners, site administrators, and developers alike. 


During this WordPress Practitioners meetup, Taylor Christensen will ease us into the new WordPress REST API by explaining the logic behind APIs, and walk through a few practical uses for both personal and client websites. 

This talk will focus more on implementations and use cases than actual code, so don't worry if you’re unfamiliar with JavaScript or have little to no coding experience.

We look forward to seeing you there. Bring your questions and your laptop. The seating at Build-a-Sign can difficult if you are very tall or have a tricky back, so when in doubt, bring a camp chair for your comfort.
name: Viewing WordPress as an Application...An Introduction to the REST API

desc:
This month's Advanced WordPress Developer meeting will feature our own Pete Nelson. For those new members who might not yet had the pleasure of sitting in in on one of Pete's classes, you are in for a treat. Pete is a Senior Web Engineer @10up, the creator of Bacon Ipsum, hunter of fine craft beers and  a connoisseur of worthy whiskies and bourbons...all that, and his code is impeccable.

Pete will be exploring creating custom permalinks for your posts, pages, custom post types, taxonomies, etc, as well as rewrite rules and custom query handling for inbound requests. 

This will be an Advance WordPress Developer Level Presentation. Our great sponsor WP Engine will provide munchies and soft drinks. 

For those who want an after-meeting code chat, we will be adjourning downstairs to the 'A' bar.
name: Advanced Permalinks in WordPress

desc:
CHANGE IN NORMAL WORDPRESS OFFICE HOURS SCHEDULE!

Scheduling February Office Hours became problematic with several of our regular Word-Head volunteers are either out of town or tied up with previous commitments. 

Based on WordHead Volunteer availability Office Hours  will be held the FIRST FRIDAY of March. 

Toyin Akinmusuru  will once again open his HubAustin Coworking Space to host WordPress Office Hours.

Our WPATX "WordHeads" will be available to answer questions and help solve site problems. Thinking of this time as an extension of the Q&A time offered after our regular Austin WordPress meetups.  


Come with your laptops and access yet another source of "free" WordPress advice within our growing Austin WordPress community. 

If you are a little further along in your WordPress Journey, please feel free to drop by and help someone else who is just learning. The more WPATX volunteers we have on hand the faster we can help our WP Office hour attendees get over the hump that has them stuck.

We really need UX /UI 'Front-end volunteers as most of the questions these past few months have been centered on " My theme won't....!" 

Right now we are limiting Office Hours to 10 attendees. 

If we get more WordHead Volunteers we will increase attendee number. 


If you think you are ready to volunteer to help other WordPress users, please come and get your Word Head Help Hat on.

We are looking forward to seeing you there. Thx - Sandi
name: WordPress Office Hours

desc:
A discussion about starting and building a successful  freelance business…

Last month we discussed the tools and processes that can help our members build an efficient, effective Freelance business. Several members contacted us and asked us to follow up that presentation with a straight forward conversation about how to find and build a profitable client base. So in  this month’s Deep Dive Discussion, Nick and Sandi Batik will focus on how to find and on-board clients for your freelance business, even if you are an introvert.

We understand that it can seem rather daunting to start your own WordPress freelancing business. The Deep Dive Discussion will address where to  start; what specialized services you are best suited to offer;  and how to find clients. Our goal is to examine how to build a healthy freelancer practice that supports you and delights your clients.
name: The Introverts Guide to Finding Clients

desc:
Beaver Builder is a drag and drop front-end WordPress page builder that works with almost any theme. It is a powerful and flexible drag and drop design system beloved by experienced WordPress developers and helpful for beginners who want to take control of their  website.


Rich Plakas will demonstrate how Beaver Builder's prebuilt templates and intuitive drag and drop design system lets users create  content-rich pages quickly and easily.  He will show how to use Beaver Builder to position text and images with the WordPress editor. Beaver Builder's front end drag and drop interface gives WordPress Beginners total control over site layout without writing any code.

This will be an engaging demonstration of one of the most helpful tool to come along in several years. We look forward to seeing you there.
name: Why Beaver Builder is a Great Tool for WordPress Beginners

desc:
This month's WordPress Practitioner's Meetup is the first in a series of "The Business of WordPress" topics our member's have requested. Our WP Practitioners attendees are about evenly divided between business owners and mangers who use WordPress daily in their businesses, and WordPress Freelancers, Developers and Implementors who are building and maintaining WordPress sites for businesses. When I read your topic requests, I approached small business specialist, Sarah Flaherty about presenting to our group. 

Sarah's tag line is, “Let me think outside the box for you,” illustrates her love for helping emerging businesses and her creativity. In today’s world, there is no unique business, there is only uniqueness. Finding your unique voice is the first and foremost need of a successful business or Freelancer. 

Your firm’s voice is the single­most important business fundamental, and it is often ignored in our WordPress Community of Developers and Designers. Consumers no longer shop locally, they shop globally ­ on their terms. This makes competition to get their attention, and keep it, fierce. You must be in constant communication with your clients in order to maintain sales and growth. However, you can’t achieve this through a great logo and a fabulous website. You must engage directly with your clients, and this requires you to have a curated voice; consumers flock to you and become your loyal evangelists when they hear and experience your care of them consistently ­ when they know your firm's personality, what and why it's passionate about, and what they can always count on. 


Sarah C. Flaherty of LUV, LLC will briefly discuss the need to find your voice, how to shape it, and what to do with it once you’ve found it ­ with a focus on social media. This presentation will be followed by a group project that allows you to take a company from conception to initial client communication and will show you the importance of aligning your company’s mission statement with your visuals and content. This will help you better understand your need to content curate to find your firm's unique voice and how to use it going forward.

With Sarah’s help, you’ll find that not only will you better understand the hows and whys of what you want to do, but you’ll be better able to focus potential clients’ attention on your business, and keep it.


We look forward to seeing you there. Bring your questions and your laptop. The seating at Build-a-Sign can difficult if you are very tall or have a tricky back, so when in doubt, bring a camp chair for your comfort.
name: Finding Your Company’s Voice

desc:
Interested in hanging out with other WordPress Developers in a"hive mind" environment? Then this month's Developer's Coding Dojo is for you. 

There is no set topic or presenter — so bring your laptop, a coding project you have been putting off, and an appetite. Our Sponsor, WP Engine, will host the meeting and will be providing Pizza and soft drinks to keep our WPATX Devs fueled through the Coding Dojo.

Come join us for some coding — this is a great opportunity to practice some WP code chops, and meet other WordPress Developers in our community. We hope to see you here.
name: Advanced WordPress Developer Dojo

desc:
The idea of do_action* is simple --- as a community we will spend one day building brand new WordPress sites for 10 deserving non-profit organizations that are based in Austin. We will start and complete every site on the same day and, at the end of it, the 10 non-profits will each have an awesome new online presence (with free hosting) so that they can get on with the work that they do so well.


This event will take place on Friday, April 8, 2016 as a full day working event. Once all the work is completed, each team will present their work to everyone else so we can all share in what promises to be some incredible website builds by the local community. After the presentations, we will all share in a celebratory dinner and drinks at the same venue - giving us all time to unwind and relax together after a hugely productive day of using WordPress to uplift the city around us.

We'll also provide breakfast and lunch and well as tea/coffee to keep you fueled throughout the day.


Schedule

We’ll be keeping things pretty flexible during the day to give you as much time to focus on building the sites as possible, but this will be the general schedule for the day:


8:00am - Check-in & breakfast

8:45am - Opening remarks

9:00am - Morning build session

12:30pm - Lunch

1:30pm - Afternoon build session

5:30pm - Site presentations

6:30pm - Closing remarks

7:00pm - Dinner & drinks

You don't have to stay for the presentations or the dinner if you have somewhere you need to be that evening, but team members are expected to be there for the full working session -- dropping in for an hour or two won't really work with this format. 


Who Should Attend?

This event requires two kinds of participants - representatives from 10 non-profit organizations, and participants and volunteers from the local WordPress community to build the sites and help run the event.


Team Members (You!) and Volunteers

Participation in this event is not just for developers! Each organization’s site has a unique set of roles that are required for it to be built effectively - from project managers to designers, content creators, developers and social media managers. If you would like to participate in one of the teams then simply fill in this form with the organization and role you would like: 


Volunteer Signup Form: http://goo.gl/forms/2hjEXfSH0q


All teams will be assigned in advance via that form. Everything you need for building the websites will be provided for you - all you need to do is bring your laptop (with power cable!) and you can get to work. If you are interested in volunteering to help run the event or to help with logistics, please also fill in the form and let us know. 

The non-profit organizations are:


• North Austin Community Media (aka KXPE-LP)

• The Blood Center of Central Texas

• Refugee Services of Texas

• PelotonU

• Circle of Health International

• Black Fret

• AIDS Services of Austin

• Texas PACE Authority

• Day With Daddy

• Austin Kids First


*do_action is the name of an event series just like this one that has been happening in the Cape Town, South Africa WordPress community. As part of the WordPress meetup program's effort to foster more cross-cultural collaboration between groups, this event will be co-organized by David Cole from Austin and Hugh Lashbrooke from the Cape Town community, who has organized events there. Have a look here for some info about one of the previous do_action events held in Cape Town, including a recap video covering the event.


Support for this event comes from:

• The WordPress Foundation

• Bluehost -- free hosting for the non-profits

• WooCommerce -- thanks for the meals and the party!

Thanks, sponsors!
name: do_action: WordPress Charity Hackathon

desc:
An on-going discussion about starting and building a successful freelance business…


Last month we discussed finding clients for your Freelance business. At this month’s Deep Dive Discussion, Nick and Sandi Batik will demonstrate tools and processes that will help you write a winning proposal, even if you are an introvert.

Right-brained or left brained, creative or analytical, the Introverted Freelancer needs to suss out what problem your client is asking you to solve. We’ll talk about how to define the client’s problem and convert that problem statement into a proposal the defines how you will  meet the clients’ needs and help improve their bottom line.

We understand that it can seem rather daunting to start your own WordPress freelancing business. Our goal is to examine how to build a healthy freelancer practice that supports you and delights your clients.
name: Introverted Freelancer’s Guide to Writing a Winning Proposal
