desc:
Learn the ins and outs of web components at this month's GDG meetup. Corey Butler will explain how to work with "raw" web component technology including Shadow DOM and Custom Elements. Corey will be followed by Pete Carapetyan will share his experience building PolyRest using Google's Polymer libraries for web components.

About Corey Butler

Corey is the author of the Fenix Web Server (fenixwebserver.com) and many Node.js tools/modules including NVM for Windows and native process runners for Windows/OSX/Linux. He is also the co-organizer of the Bleeding Edge Web meetup and a technical reviewer for Pragmatic Bookshelf (most recently Developing Android on Android). He can be found at github.com/coreybutler and coreybutler.com.

About Pete Carapetyan

Pete is a long long time developer who has grown to appreciate JavaScript.
name: Web Components & Polymer

desc:
We're trying something new at the April meetup. One room will have a talk on writing Android apps in Kotlin. The other room will have a talk on Functional Reactive Programming using JavaScript.

Most of our members are either Android developers or JavaScript developers but each meetup is usually geared towards one group or the other. This month we're teaming up with the Austin Droids to have a meetup with two tracks.

Come to the talk you're interested in and meet local developers from both disciplines before and after.

Kotlin for Android

Jim Baca will be presenting on Kotlin, the new popular JVM language for faster easier Android development. Kotlin has now reached version 1.0. It is recommended by Jake Wharton and used by a number of companies including Prezi, GMC and 3D Robotics.

This presentation covers:
1) Why language choice matters
2) Kotlin syntax
3) Benefits of Kotlin

Jim has been an Android developer since 2010 working on different android apps in different fields such as entertainment, WiFi hardware management, video system surveillance and management, solar hardware installation and reporting. He actively publishes articles pertaining to Android such as http://blog.jimbaca.com/2016/03/28/exploring-tiles-in-android-n-preview-release/ and
http://blog.jimbaca.com/2016/03/07/go-with-the-flow-handling-configuration-changes-with-flow/

Functional Reactive Programming by Example

Ryan Vice will show how to get up to speed on FRP and one-way data flows. The talk includes an introduction to FRP using RXJS and a comparison of three implementations of the same app. One implements Flux in React using Redux. The second uses RXJS and the third uses Bacon. The comparison will highlight the benefits of FRP over Flux.

Ryan is a software consultant with 16 years experience. He is founder of Vice Software LLC, a consulting company specializing in practical modern web development. He is the author of two books on architecture and programming including "Mastering React" (Packt Publishing Feb 2016).
name: Room 1: Kotlin on Android & Room 2:Functional Reactive Programming in JavaScript

desc:
This event is intended for junior high, high school, college students, parents and educators who want to learn about Google's Summer of Code (for college interns) and Google Code-In (for ages 13 - 17).

Stephanie Taylor from Google will give an overview of these programs and do Q&A. Come learn about them and how you or your children can participate.

Also, Ryan Torbey a K-5 technology teach and co-organizer of the Texas Alliance for Computer Science Education (TACSE) will share a brief overview of the state of computer science education in Texas as well as opportunities to get involved.
name: Google Programs for Students: Summer of Code and Code-In

desc:
Progressive Web Apps provide an app-like user experience. They can be launched from an icon on the home screen, render quickly, use hardware features such as GPS, and work offline.

This months meetup is based on the Progressive Web App Dev Summit in Amsterdam on June 20th and 21st. We will watch a portion of the keynote, discuss the associated technology and then offer several code labs that attendees can choose from and work through for the remainder of the event. A few prizes will also be given out at the end of the labs.
name: Progressive Web Apps - Keynote & Code Lab

desc:
Historically Android development wasn't so great. Writing an Android app meant lots of boilerplate  and writing the same types of classes over and over and over. Thankfully, things are much better now. In recent years Google and the Android community have really stepped up to create tools and open source libraries that take care of many things, allowing you to focus on writing the fun code. In this talk we'll cover some of the best tools and libraries out there, and allow you to weigh in on your favorites as well!


Andrew Watson from GoPro will be presenting.
name: Android Library Love

desc: This Thursday Dave Powell will give an intro to TensorFlow, the open source machine learning library released by Google last November. TensorFlow can run in many environments from machine clusters to Android and iOS devices. See how your software can benefit from neural networks.
name: Intro to TensorFlow - Machine Learning from Google

desc:
Hi all!

Let's explore the current state and characteristics of Natural Language Processing. 

Natural Language Processing is becoming more accessible and Mike Johns, Director of Research and Trading at Lake Austin Advisors, will give us some insight into what it is all about.

Areas we will explore are:

What is the Vision of NLP vs Reality?

Overview of approaches to NLP: Symbolic vs Statistical


Recent Breakthroughs in NLP


Where NLP is at today?

Thank you to Spanning for hosting us in their office!

Darran
name: An Introduction to Natural Language Processing with Mike Johns

desc: Got some weekend coding to do? Come work on it at Cherrywood Cafe with other GDG developers or just hang out and chat.
name: Code Cafe

The recent startup boom has created some of the world’s fastest growing new companies, and the strategies and methodologies they used can also be leveraged by employees and enterprises of all sizes to create innovation. 

If you would like to learn how, then join us on our free "How Employees Can Innovate Like Entrepreneurs" webinar.

This webinar will be hosted by Adeo Ressi (Founder & CEO of the Founder Institute), and feature special guest David Kidder, best-selling author of "The Startup Playbook", and Co-Founder and CEO of numerous successful companies - such as Clickable (acquired by Syncapse), SmartRay Network (acquired by LifeMinders), and Net-X (acquired by Target Vision). Through David’s most recent company, Bionic, he has helped some of the world’s largest companies become more entrepreneurial, like GE, Boeing, and Tyco. 

On this webinar you will learn: 

- How employees can adopt the same entrepreneurial strategies and tools used by the world’s most successful entrepreneurs 

- How employees can instill a “builder-mentality” in their organizations from the ground up 

- How company leaders can build an entrepreneurial culture in organizations of any size, to facilitate quick learning, risk taking, and exponential growth. 


We hope you will join us!

Combining the best of Customer Development, Design Thinking, Lean Startup, and Growth Hacking, Justin's "FOCUS Framework" (http://j.mp/_F0CUS) lays out an actionable path to validating your startup ideas, and achieving "Product-Market Fit." 

To learn how to validate your ideas, join our free "How to Quickly Validate Your Startup Ideas" webinar, taking place athttp://fi.co/webinars.

...to validate your startup idea, and find your Product-Market Fit.

Publicity can provide any business with a massive advantage.. but how can you get it for free as a startup? Join this webinar to learn how to generate buzz for your company, how to work with reporters, and the latest strategies for getting publicity, from two serial entrepreneurs who have both been featured on some of the world's largest publications (for free). 

This webinar will be hosted by Adeo Ressi (Founder & CEO of the Founder Institute), and feature special guest Philip Kaplan. 

Philip has been a serial entrepreneur since the 90s, creating massive press for himself while starting companies like Adbrite (one of the world’s pioneering online ad networks), Tiny Letter (a free newsletter service acquired by MailChimp), and F**ked Company (a massively popular parody site that chronicled the dot.com crash in the early 2000s). Currently, he is the Founder & CEO of DistroKid (a service that musicians use to get their music into iTunes, Spotify, and other digital music stores). 

On this webinar you will learn: 

- How to generate buzz for yourself, or your business/ startup 

- How to work effectively with reporters 

- The latest strategies for getting free publicity 

We hope you will join us!

Combining the best of Customer Development, Design Thinking, Lean Startup, and Growth Hacking, Justin's "FOCUS Framework" (http://j.mp/_F0CUS) lays out an actionable path to validating your startup ideas, and achieving "Product-Market Fit."

“Growth hacker” has become a hot job title, because marketers need to increasingly become more technical (and vice versa). However, while “hacking” growth may lead to short term wins for your company, the companies that build and adopt a longterm process for growth engine are the ones that ultimately succeed. On this webinar, we will discuss how to create a sustainable growth engine for your product or company.

This webinar will be hosted by Adeo Ressi (Founder & CEO of the Founder Institute), and feature special guest Justin Wu. 

Justin Wu is the Co-Founder of Sidevision and Vytmn (http://vytmn.com), the leading "growth as-a-service" company that uses the latest growth techniques to help businesses get more customers, and more revenue.  Justin is also the Resident Growth Hacker at Start Engine Accelerator.

On this webinar you will learn: 

• What metrics should certain types of businesses prioritize, and what metrics should they ignore?

• What are the various channels to create growth, what are the benefits and drawbacks for each channel, and where should you start?

• How can you test channels effectively, and optimize your customer funnel for longterm success?

We hope you will join us!

The power of online communities is undeniable. In fact, the most valuable businesses of the past decade have all achieved massive growth through the power of network effects and strong online communities. On the “How to Create a Strong Online Community” webinar, experts with years of experience will teach you the key components to a strong online community, as well as actionable tactics to make your community more engaged and active.

This interactive Q&A webinar will be hosted by Adeo Ressi (Founder & CEO of the Founder Institute), and feature special guest Gina Bianchini. 

Gina Bianchini is an expert in creating specialized social networks online and in the real world. She is the Founder and CEO of Mightybell (http://mightybell.com), which offers professional social networks with a purpose. Before Mightybell, Bianchini and Marc Andreessen co-founded Ning, the largest social platform for communities of interests online. Gina is also the Co-Founder of the Lean In Movement (http://LeanIn.org), the largest global movement to offer women with inspiration and support to help them achieve their goals.

On this webinar you will learn: 

• The secret to the success of every vibrant online community

• The metrics you need to focus on to drive meaningful community growth

• The 3 main reasons people join communities (and how you create better marketing copy)

• 8 actionable tactics to increase engagement in your community

We hope you will join us!

PR is one of the most cost effective ways a startup can begin building thought leadership, brand recognition, and a customer base. Unfortunately, many entrepreneurs don't know where to get started or how to deal with journalists - so they hire an expensive PR firm, or ignore PR entirely. 

On this free, interactive webinar, two startup PR experts with decades of experience will guide you on how to start leveraging PR at your startup. 

This interactive Q&A webinar will be hosted by Adeo Ressi (Founder & CEO of the Founder Institute, 9X entrepreneur and investor), and feature special guest Conrad Egusa.

Conrad is the CEO of Publicize (http://publicize.co), a startup aiming to change the way companies approach PR. He has been featured in publications including The Financial Times and Bloomberg, and has been a guest contributor for TechCrunch, VentureBeat and TheNextWeb. Conrad is also a Global Mentor at 500 Startups, The Founder Institute, ANDI (Asociación Nacional de Empresarios de Colombia), and the Spanish accelerator Zarpamos.

During this event, Adeo and Conrad will discuss: 

- How to properly strategize your PR efforts 
- How to grow yourself as a thought leader 
- How to get your company featured - all without the help of a big PR firm. 
- How to write an effective press release 
- The tips and tricks of dealing with journalists 

We hope you will join us!

desc:
This is a free, online event that you can participate in from your computer. To join and get the access link, you must register at https://app.webinarjam.net/register/24710/9fbc123101 . If you can't make it, you can still register on that page to get the video recording after the event!   

----

Business success should be measured not just by profit, but by social impact as well. Unfortunately, most startups being formed today focus on squeezing profit out of solving small problems, for small markets. If bright-minded entrepreneurs tackled bigger problems and global markets, not only would their potential to achieve big profit AND societal impact be much higher - they could also lead a more inspired and passionate life. 

On this free, interactive webinar, we will discuss various topics around creating an impactful company with special guest Kimbal Musk. 

Kimbal Musk is on the board for Tesla Motors, SpaceX, and Chipotle Mexican Grill. His personal mission is to strengthen communities through food. Kimbal is a co-founder of The Kitchen, a growing family of restaurants that sources directly from local farmers, stimulating the local farm economy to the tune of millions of dollars a year, and creating quality jobs. In 2011, Kimbal co-founded The Kitchen Community, a complementary non-profit organization. The Kitchen Community builds Learning Gardens in schools around the U.S. reaching hundreds of thousands of students every school day, improving their vegetable intake and academic achievements. 

During this event, Adeo Ressi (Founder & CEO of the Founder Institute) and Kimbal will discuss topics like:  

• The various business opportunities where entrepreneurs can start impactful companies 

• How to identify the "big idea" that you are passionate about solving 

• How to create an impactful vision, define your mission, and articulate them to the masses

• How to navigate the funding landscape for social and mission-driven companies

• Why food is an impactful and trillion dollar business opportunity 

We hope you will join us!

---

name: Creating an Impactful Company: A Chat with Kimbal Musk (Online Event)

Customer interviews are both the most important, and the most difficult, step to finding Product-Market Fit and ensuring that you build a product that customers want. 

- How do you find people to interview?

- How do you not bias their answers? 
- When are you done interviewing?

To answer these questions, and master customer interviews, register for FOCUS Con (http://focuscon2.splashthat.com/FIFounder) - a fully digital conference where you'll get: 


- 4+ hours of live interactive video-workshops

desc:
Apache Mesos and the new Open Source Architecture of the Modern Datacenter

Apache Mesos has the ability to run on every private and cloud instance, anywhere. In this talk, Tobi Knaup, Mesosphere CTO, will explain the momentum behind the “single computer” abstraction that has put Mesos at the center of one of the most exciting architecture shifts in recent information technology history. He will explain how Mesos is enabling application developers and devops to redefine their responsibilities and shorten the amount of time it takes to write and ship production code. He will outline how Mesos is empowering the new class of “datacenter developers” to program directly against datacenter resources, and draw correlations to how the Linux revolutionized the server industry.


(Note: the May meetup is moved back a few days to accomodate our special guest)

desc:
Cloud.  Security.  Often those words then unleash a bunch of nonsense. So here's what we're going to do.

First, Tristan Slominski will do a 10 minute demo on "Onetime pattern - how to put your secrets in user-data and get away with it."


With operating in AWS comes the problem of how to configure the servers with secrets. In this short presentation, Tristan Slominski proposes a pattern of bootstrapping new servers with secrets using onetime read guarantees.


Then, we'll do openspaces!  This is a self organizing format where we talk about topics proposed by the group at hand. The umbrella topic will be cloud security - the real issues and successes you are having. What do you have nailed with the awesome powers of cloud/SaaS/DevOps/fun tools?  What are the real security issues you have on a daily basis and wish you had a better solution for? I suspect "secrets" will be high on the list, as well as auth in this crazy containerized world we find ourselves in. But you'll tell us what we should discuss on site!

Sponsor: ObjectRocket by Rackspace

Bring your laptops for this one!

Come join us for a discussion on how HomeDepot.com has evolved over the years. Hear about the challenges and successes faced while moving this multi billion dollars site to cloud native patterns.

desc:
We have two talks this month - one on containers and one on online authentication!

What Are Containers And Why Are They So Important, by Derrick Wippler

Struggling to understand all the hype around Docker? Don't understand the difference between a VM and a container? Why are immutable operating systems cool? Why is everyone going crazy over Kubernetes/Swarm/Apache Mesos? 

This talk will attempt to inform by pulling back the curtain on the container hype. We will dissect what a container is, why clustering containers and orchestration matters, immutable operating systems and finally where this is all going and how it will effect your future interaction with the cloud. 

Derrick Wippler is: Tech Geek, Container evangelist, Software Developer, Entrepreneur and Rackspace Cloud Block Storage Imagineer. Creator of a SuperNES emulator (http://www.superretro16.com). And you can read my musings on technology on my blog (http://thrawn01.org)

Who Are You?  From Meat To Electrons And Back Again, by Mike Schwartz

Conventional wisdom tells us to use two-factor authentication—and it does help to improve security. But the best way to reduce user-friction is to never require a person to authenticate. This talk will provide a modern solution to reconcile these two divergent imperatives by leveraging standard profiles of OAuth2 for trust elevation. Its not just the front door that needs protection!

Mike Schwartz is the Founder of Gluu, a security software company serving companies, governments and universities around the world. Schwartz is a domain expert in application security, authentication and API access management. The Gluu Server is one of the leading implementations of OpenID Connect. Schwartz has participated in the development of standards like the User Managed Access (UMA) profile of OAuth2, a new standard for API access management. He is also Co-chair of the Open Trust Taxonomy for OAuth2 (OTTO) working group at Kantara to create new standards for multiparty federation. Before starting Gluu, Schwartz was a security integrator for many large enterprises. He also was the Founder of an ISP in the '90s. He now resides with his family (and pigeons) in Austin, TX.

Sponsor : CenturyLink

Also, we will be raffling off a Bronze pass to OSCON, coming to Austin this May!

Email: [masked]

desc:
Date: Thursday, April 21, 2016
Time: 10am PDT / 1pm EDT
Register Here

Join us to learn all about Docker. Interested, but can't attend? Register anyway and we'll send you the recording.

Early adopters report "easier replication, faster deployment and lower configuration and operating costs" of applications that involve Docker containers - an open platform that allows developers and sysadmins to build, ship and execute distributed applications.

Not surprisingly then, a groundswell of organizations are interested in evaluating Docker containers in proof-of-concept initiatives and/or pilot projects. The transition to production use, however, introduces additional requirements as Docker containers need to be incorporated into existing IT infrastructures and (ultimately) integrated into application workflows.

The aim of this webinar is to provide a technical overview and demonstration of Docker and to frame its use within the context of High Performance Computing and Big Data Analytics.
name: [webinar] Docker 101

desc:
We're going to do 2 awesome presentations this month- one with our friends from Elastic and another from Matt Ray from Chef!

6:00pm-6:20pm: Welcome

6:20pm-7:10pm: What's powering the Elastic Cloud Saas by Erik Redding

7:10pm-8:00pm: Habitat by Matt Ray

Talk #1: What's Powering the Elastic Cloud ESaaS

Elastic Cloud (formerly known as Found) has been using some form of containers since it's inception.  The platform has encountered a few technology transitions, namely from LXC to Docker, and has leveraged the content delivery of Docker to reduce administrative burdens across the board.  We'll explore the use of AWS, Docker, and of course Elasticsearch while painting the picture of what makes the official Elasticsearch-As-A-Service work.  


Speaker: Erik Redding, Elastic

Talk #2: Chef's New Habitat

What https://bignews.chef.io/ is all about!  OK now that it's been announced, we can speak freely, it's Habitat (https://www.habitat.sh/). ;

Speaker: Matt Ray, Chef

Food Sponsor: Elastic
name: Double Header: Elastic Cloud + Habitat Double Header

desc:
6:00PM: Welcome and announcements

6:20PM: Main topic: Kubernetes me this.

Google Kubernetes is an open-source system for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications. 

What does that mean? If you’re thinking about moving towards a container-centric world then you should consider using Kubernetes. In this talk I’ll go through the architecture of Kubernetes and give an overview of how it works, capping it off with a tech demo and light Q and A.

Speaker: Richard Boyd II

Sponsor: Wayblazer

Email: [masked]
name: Kubernetes me this....

desc:
Featured Talk:

Cloud Native Data and Analytics tools

Data and Analytics services is where the latest innovation in the Cloud is taking place. With Microsoft and Google pushing out new tools in the space AWS is having to do catchup on it’s lead there. We’ll spend 2 hrs going thru all the data related services that are offered from AWS, Azure and Google and do a compare and contrast of the services where appropriate.


Here’s some of the service I’ll be talking about:

• AWS EMR, Redshift, Kinesis, Data Pipeline, QuickSight, Machine Learning and more

• Azure HDInsight, Data Lake Store, Data Lake Analytics, Machine Learning, Stream Analytics, Data Factory and more

• Google BigQuery, Cloud Dataflow, Cloud Dataproc, Cloud Datalab, Machine Learning and more.

This talk is intended to be an overview of the services since there’s a lot to cover here, time permitting we can deep dive into a few. Most of you will be familiar with the AWS tools, but the same really can’t be said for Azure and Google and here’s a chance to catch up on what’s been brewing there.

Speaker: Nirmal Ranganathan, Rackspace

Sponsor: Stormpath, the excellent cloud identity provider!
name: Cloud Native Data and Analytics tools

desc:
This week we have two talks back to back!  One on the orchestration framework Rundeck, and one on a new Microsoft Azure feature, DocumentDB.


We still need a sponsor though! Hit us up at [masked] to volunteer.

Rundeck at Wayblazer, by Kevin Cashman

Problems we needed to solve   

• Engineers need to run jobs on-demand and scheduled   

• They want a GUI  

•  Ops doesn't want people SSHing onto servers hacking crontabs 

What is rundeck?   

• Job execution framework with GUI focus   

• Jobs made up of workflow steps   

• Open source   

• Optional Enterprise Support 

• How Rundeck solved the problem   

• Flexible options   

• Scalable 

Implementation details   

• Projects and Jobs   

• Node management   

• User Management   

• Backend on MySQL RDS 

Pitfalls   

• Some issues with:   

• user environment   

• process exit status 

• Questions


by Kevin Cashman, DevOps @ WayBlazer 

DocumentDB, by Chander Dhall

Abstract: Have you worked on no-sql databases in the cloud like Mongodb, Cassandra etc? Want to work on something that has both a sql kind syntax and has an API in  Node.js, .Net, Java etc? Something that scales the entire office 365? In this presentation, internationally acclaimed speaker and Microsoft awarded Most Valuable Professional will do a deep dive in DocumentDb - a No-sql database that runs on Azure. 


Bio: Chander Dhall is a Microsoft MVP, Tech Ed Speaker, ASP.NETInsider, Web API Advisor, Dev Chair - DevConnections professional software architect/lead developer, trainer, INETA speaker, open source contributor, community leader and organizer with years of experience in enterprise Software Development. Chander started coding when he was 6 and created his first successful software product at the age of 14. He is the President and CEO of Chander Dhall Inc. 

Chander has a proven track record of making clients successful and saving millions of dollars to them. He is the Dev Chair of Dev Connections and he works in a goal oriented, technologically driven, fast paced AGILE (SCRUM) environment. He is the founder of Dallas day of dot net, MVPMIX.comand jsSaturday. He has a Master's Degree in computer science with specialization in algorithms, principles and patterns and is focused on building high performing modular software. 

Chander leads the iPhone Developers Dallas, Angularjs Austin and Rockstar Developers Austin user groups. Chander recently got recognized as 'One of the top organizers' by Eventbrite. Chander has been a featured speaker in numerous conferences and code camps all over the world.

Sponsor

No sponsor yet, contact [masked] to buy food for this festive double shot!
name: Rundeck and Azure DocumentDB

desc:
Rob Hirschfeld, co-chair of the Kubernetes Cluster Ops SIG and cofounder of the Digital Rebar project, will discuss the components and operational choices behind building a working Kubernetes cluster.  

Kubernetes (aka K8s) is one of the leading container management platforms and emerging as a choice underlay platform for other software platform services and ISV applications.  With that in mind, we'll talk about the challenges for building and maintaining Kubernetes clusters in production.  

This will be an interactive session that assumes you've already got some Docker/container experience, so bring your questions and prepare to be lively!

desc:
This month, we're doing a super special meetup joining forces with the Microservices and Containers Austin meetup led by Lee Calcote, and having the folks from Mirantis present on a class on Kubernetes 101 with Docker containers on Openstack.

Abstract:

Kubernetes 101 provides a high-level introduction into the fundamental concepts of containerization technology and basic features of Kubernetes, open-source container orchestration platform. During this 90-minute session, we will briefly cover different aspects of using Docker and Kubernetes with OpenStack. We will discuss running containers in OpenStack, installing a Kubernetes cluster on top of OpenStack, as well as using and orchestrating an OpenStack containerized control plane.

Speaker Bio:

Chris Caillouet is a Senior Technical Instructor for Mirantis who is based out of San Antonio, Texas. Chris has worked with OpenStack since its inception and is a founding member of OpenStack and the community ecosystem. Chris has been instructing OpenStack for over 5 years and has experienced a lifetime immersion into hardware and software technologies and evolutions as a passion and career path. 

Sponsor:

Mirantis, The Pure Play OpenStack Company, will be sponsoring Austin's Pizza tonight!
name: Kubernetes+Docker+Op­enstack 101

Nando Cabán-Méndez (a.k.a. @NandoJourneyman) is an experienced business and online marketing consultant. As a multi-disciplinary designer he has over two decades of design experience including print, web design, industrial design, environmental graphics, product and sportswear design, online user experience and interfaces, and business workflow design.

His entrepreneurship experience includes startups in manufacturing, online retail, and B2B services. desc:
It's been quite a while since we continued the SEO School series, but we're excited to get it going again this year. Picking up where we left off in the series, after having a plan and conducting a competitive analysis, the next thing we want to look at is design and UX for SEO.

Design and UX for SEO

We all know that optimizing your website for SEO is important, but sacrificing user experience for SEO gains is the wrong way to go. When done correctly design and UX should work in tandem and benefit the SEO. To learn more about this  topic join us for this meeting and listen to one of Austin's specialist on this matter. Don't forget to bring your ideas and questions! 

 Samantha Fagan

Samantha is a storyteller who is passionate about design. For the past eight years, she has helped craft the stories of people and brands in print and on the web. She is the full package: a web designer with a print background who can hand-code HTML/CSS and WordPress, develop a cohesive online marketing strategy, and manage clients.

This course is designed for those learning SEO, freelancers, small business owners and others looking to enhance their business through SEO. There will be many guest speakers, a questions and answers portion, and additional time for one-on-one interactions.

We had a bit of a break this summer. We're now starting the meetings back up and we thought it would be good to kick things off with a little Meet and Greet. We'll have a few questions we ask everyone as a way to get introduced. Aside from that, it's going to be a pretty open format.

desc:
Remember to check out our other upcoming events after you decide to RSVP for this event which WebProATX is cross promoting.


You’ve heard all about coding bootcamps, but what are they really? 

• What do you learn? 

• Can you really get a job right out of a coding bootcamp? 

• Will you even like coding? 

• Can’t you just teach yourself online for free?

No doubt these are many of the questions that are running through your mind if you’re thinking about switching careers to become a software developer. 

During this info/Q&A session we’ll answer any questions you have about making the leap and attending a coding school.

This event is FREE! We'll provide light snacks and refreshments; please RSVP via Eventbrite so we have an accurate head count and can plan accordingly!

http://www.eventbrite.com/e/learn-to-code-austin-coding-bootcamps-qa-at-google-fiber-tickets-20763909412?aff=ausLTC

As a leader in this space Galvanize is excited to help more people in Austin make the transition to careers as software developers. With campuses in Denver/Boulder, San Francisco and Seattle we’re excited to add Austin to the list of cities we call home.

We’re excited to meet you and answer any and all questions you may have! 

Meet Your Speaker:

Graham McBain lives in Denver with his amazing wife Alissa. Graham is a graduate of the 3rd cohort of the Galvanize Full Stack Program. Graham believes that programming is more accessible than people think and is passionate about showing people the path to becoming a developer.

About Our Sponsor:

Galvanize is an education company that blends the lines between learning and working. We believe in creating easy access for anyone who has the drive and determination to jump into the tech world, especially in entrepreneurship, engineering, and data science. Our campuses are home to students, startups, investors, mentors, and other people who are engaged and excited to level up their skills. To learn more about Galvanize, visit galvanize.com.


This event is FREE! We'll provide light dinner and refreshments; please RSVP via Eventbrite so we have an accurate head count and can plan accordingly!
http://www.eventbrite.com/e/learn-to-code-austin-coding-bootcamps-qa-at-google-fiber-tickets-20763909412?aff=ausLTC
name: ~>Galvanize Has Invited Us to Join Them at Google Fiber Coding Bootcamp Q&A :)

desc:

http://www.eventbrite.com/e/galvanize-data-science-immersive-info-session-tickets-21226998524?aff=ausDS

There are plenty of articles and discussions on the web about what data science is, what qualities define a data scientist, and how you should position yourself to be a competitive applicant. 

There are far fewer resources out there that explain the concrete steps to take in order to obtain the skills necessary to break into this fast-growing industry. 

Join us for a discussion about how to start working towards a career in data science at Galvanize. You'll leave this event understanding both on-your-own and structured options for beginning your career in a data science role. You will also have a list of the best resources to use to plan your studies.

SCHEDULE

6:00 PM: Doors Open
6:30 PM: Overview of Data Science Immersive program and curriculum at Galvanize
7:00 PM: Q&A and Networking


<a href="http://www.eventbrite.com/e/galvanize-data-science-immersive-info-session-tickets-21226998524?aff=ausDS"></a>

desc:
Be sure to check out our other events to RSVP for this week and next month.

So back in 2014 one of our teams got second place at a Hackathon for helping "Heroes Night Out" with a complete website infrastructure remake in under 24 hours, helping them reach thousands of Veterans in Central Texas get the help they need that they could not find elsewhere. :)


Now I am glad to announce another hackathon where we will be having a HUGE POSITIVE impact on veterans in our local central Texas communities.

Join us for a hackathon event to develop brain health innovations for Veterans experiencing mild TBI (mTBI) and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). 

Register here


What are we hacking? 
We are focused on developing innovations that improve access to care for Veterans faced with mTBI and PTSD, along with identifying innovations in diagnostics, rehabilitation, and community reintegration. 


Free food and drinks will be provided.

Whose Data? 
The Department of Veterans Affairs, U of Texas at Dallas Brain Institute as well as potentially the Pentagon will be releasing Open data sets the day of the hackathon! 

Who can participate? 
Everyone. Veterans, caregivers, clinicians, researchers, developers, technologists, designers, data scientists, and citizens. Really everyone. Experts and thought leaders in mTBI and PTSD will serve as team mentors, including several VA subject matter experts and Veterans. 

Agenda: 
February 19: Evening networking social 
February 20: Kickoff, speakers, participant pitches, teams form, develop ideas 
February 21: Last day sprint to complete prototypes, deliver presentations to judging panel, winners selected 

*Note, expedite check in at Galvanize; register in advance 

This event is a collaboration between MyVA Partnerships, VA Center for Innovation, Booz Allen Hamilton, Capital Factory, and Galvanize .
name: -> CODE TO HELP LOCAL VETERANS! VA Hackathon for Brain Health mTBI & PTSD. :)

desc:
TrackHack™: the Proximity ID Hackathon is the first-ever hackathon focused solely on the proximity ID technologies that power the Internet of Things.


Whether radio frequency identification (RFID), Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) and beacons, or near field communication (NFC), these proximity ID technologies, merged with cloud-based applications enable complete interaction between the physical and digital worlds.


We are looking for developers, designers, idea folks, and pitch masters to conjure up the best proximity id applications possible. 

Build something using proximity ID technologies.

Prizes


• 1st place - $5000

• 2nd place - $3500

• 3rd place - $1500

What are my transport/parking options getting to the event? Details coming soon.   Do you provide any travel reimbursement? 


We're still working with sponsors to get the event fully funded so can't promise any reimbursement at this time. If things change as we approach the event (as they sometimes do), then we will be able to offer things like reimbursing travel. TBD.

What can/can't I bring to the event?


The space is limited. Hardware should be kept to a minimum to avoid clutter. Things like laptops, screens, handheld power tools, soldering stations, power strips, and HDMI cables are good things to bring.

------------------------------------------------------


<a href="https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Ka-ElB89pGZetjp6jyyTt5t8LDS-MHYuTfSNHCQAIMk/edit?usp=sharing"></a>

About AccelerateNFC (www.acceleratenfc.com) 

— AccelerateNFC is a technology-specific, idea incubator/seed accelerator for high potential companies in the Proximity ID space.


Accelerate NFC focuses on near field communication (NFC) and other proximity ID technologies like Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) and Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE).


We bring industry expertise, mentors, resources and funding to those companies who are ready to take their ideas and products to the next level.


Up to five selected companies will participate in an intensive 12-week mentoring program designed to provide access to resources normally beyond the reach of start-up or early stage companies.

---------------------------------------------------------


About Flomio (www.flomio.com)

Flomio creates proximity ID solutions that help enterprise clients and developers cross the chasm to web 3.0, the Internet of Things (IoT).


Funded by TechStars, Flomio is fundamentally changing the way people engage with the spaces around them by making proximity ID simple to integrate, easy to deploy, and fun to use.


Soon, 50 billion devices will regularly connect to the internet. Flomio’s platform empowers enterprise customers and developers to create applications that communicate with these devices.


The future is ubiquitous connectivity. Flomio makes sure businesses get there first.
name: ~> SXSW 2016 TrackHack Austin 2016 AccelerateNFC & Flomio Proximity ID Hackathon

desc:
The SXSW Music Hackathon Championship is today!

If your application was accepted please message me so I can assist you in participating!

I will be here till 3pm to see the hackathon off and best assist members of this meetup coming to put in their applications and or have already been accepted for the hackathon.

Arrive in lobby and ask SxSw info desk for details. I am in business attire white shirt with black vest.

Click this to go to registration page

RSVP so we know who all is going and can help coordinate teams from our members. :)


What’s NOT changing is the 24 straight hours of buzzing, high-tech creativity as scores of hackers use their programming knowledge and our collection of music-tech APIs to develop their industry-changing prototypes and compete for the huge Grand Prize, awarded by our panel of celebrity judges. The SXSW Music Hackathon is FREE and open to the public with approved application below on this page.

This year, hackers will collaborate and compete in three hack categories, with each category vying for big cash prizes and a load of bragging rights:

Commerce: how is money getting to artists and rights-holders and can blockchain technology help? Creation: how can musicians use tech to create and perform music in new ways? Consumer: how can we improve the fan or listener experience? Participating hackers get to show off their skills, play with the coolest APIs in music-tech, meet our SXSW Official Showcase Artists-in-Residence, and present to high-profile industry celeb judges in one crazy, marathon 24-hour coding experience. A variety of programming expertise is welcome to join


Click this to go to registration page
name: SXSW MUSIC HACKATHON CHAMPIONSHIP

desc:
Taco & Drinks will be provided!

You MUST Register at:
http://www.eventbrite.com/e/learn-to-code-austin-intro-to-git-and-github-tickets-22475721488?aff=ausLTC

SUMMARY:

Just in time to address those SXSW hangover blues lets recap our SXSW experiences over free tacos, drinks, and beginner level friendly intro class to Git & Github!

In this Learn to Code sponsored workshop, you'll learn the essentials of Git, the most common version control tool that millions of coders use while developing for the web. We will also learn how to use Github, a popular Git-based repository to host your projects online.

Stuff like:
How to create and work in a local repository
How to work remotely using GitHub (push and pull)
How to fork, clone, merge, and delete and branch repositories What to bring:

Bring your laptop, fully charged,
Bring your charger just in case, Install Git: http://git-scm.com/downloads Sign up for a profile with Github: https://github.com/

Install the Atom text editor if you don't have a text editor.
https://atom.io/

ARRIVE 15-20 mins early to find $8 parking nearby, and have best chance at the flavor of tacos you want before we run out! Will be expected to be standing room only! RSVP & to guarantee tacos and entry if things get crazy you MUST be on the Eventbrite list, which you join at:

http://www.eventbrite.com/e/learn-to-code-austin-intro-to-git-and-github-tickets-22475721488?aff=ausLTC And be sure to RSVP for our other upcoming events by clicking the "Home" button above! :)

desc:
BE SURE TO RSVP SO WE KNOW HOW MANY TO EXPECT & THEN CHECK OUT OUR OTHER UPCOMING EVENTS & HACKATHON!

----------------------------------------------------------------

Join us at Capital Factory for our first workshop leading up to ATX Hack for Change 2016, and learn how anyone, even people without a coding background, can hack for Austin!

And RSVP at our partners new Dabble site:

https://dabble.co/austin/coding/classes/hackathon-101-with-open-austin-st-edward-s-university-and-city-of-austin-s-innovation-office

We are partnering with


Open Austin, St. Edward's University,

City of Austin Innovation Office Coding Classes in Austin,

and the folks at Capital Factory to put on this event.

Just what is a hackathon, anyway? What is a civic hackathon?

For the last two+ years this meetup has won 3 hackathons and helped support and host 24+ hackathons, and we are making strides to host and co-organize a hackathon in Austin every month for the remainder of this year!


We'll show you just how you can take your skills - any skills, from dog walking to competitive eating - and put them to use on a project. We'll also showcase the types of projects we have worked on over the past 4 years.

Whether you are interested in being a


We will cover the basics of what you need to get started, and the tools you'll be utilizing in this engaging Q&A that will help you:

• Become a Hacker,

• Become a Project Champion,


• Learn to code in team or work environments,


• Learn about the benefits and pitfalls of different code languages so you can make a informed decision on whether to continue a education or career in that programming language,

• Learn to talk and work with other programmers and developers

• And accelerate your skills to get hired or hire other programmers and developers!

A big thanks to our sponsors Dabble and MakerSquare in making this event possible along with our hosts: St. Edward's University, Open Austin and the City of Austin Innovation Office.

This workshop will take place in the 16th floor classroom at Capital Factory which is located in the Omni Hotel. Take the elevators in the triangular lobby to the 16th floor and you will be greeted at the front desk where you can get the $5 discounted parking voucher.

YES, dinner will be served at 7 p.m. so make sure to arrive early to get it while it's hot!

What to bring Laptop, iPad, Note-taking Tools(pen & paper perhaps?)


What will be provided Refreshments + Food + Beer + Wi-Fi + People *_*


AGAIN, we expect a full house, standing room only, so please be sure to RSVP here and RSVP at our partners new Dabble site:

https://dabble.co/austin/coding/classes/hackathon-101-with-open-austin-st-edward-s-university-and-city-of-austin-s-innovation-office
name: ~>HACKATHON TRAINING WORKSHOP! FREE food, beer, drinks! Learn how code fast! :-D

desc:
I would like to welcome you, members of Webproatx, to join me and my family to to commemorate the events of Exodus and to celebrate God's plan of
salvation for us all. 


This is like the only time my birthday falls on a triple special day and the first 20 of you are welcome to join me on this very special evening!

$20 for lamb shanks, Matza balls, sweets, and more!?

Unbeatable! This is the only location I know that is offering this price! (Average is $60+ elsewhere in Austin!)

Its my birthday, its Earth day, and its Passover!

I will be securing tickets from each member that pays and rsvp's here, paying payment processor out of my own pocket, securing seats and tickets for you and awaiting you on arrival!

Will have Gluten free options too!

Will be addressing old and new Testament.


Look forwards to seeing how many of my Meetup members join me for this very special evening. :')
name: ~>ORGANIZER'S BIRTHDAY EARTH DAY PASSOVER PARTY! - No lamb shank left behind! :)

desc:
RSVP here, check out our other upcoming events, and study challenge details here: https://hackaday.io/prize/details#one

~ ~ ~

The Goal:

Form a team (or work on your own) and submit a project to the Hackaday Prize design challenge.

Need some inspiration for your project? Here are some ideas:

•Citizen Science - Build a graphene supercapacitor, study the effects of a behavior, build an open source instrumentation device.

• Automation - Build a device that makes breakfast or buys laundry detergent when you’re running low. Automatically track stuff, automate any process, build a Me-robot to do your every whim

•Assistive technologies - Build a project that helps others move better, see better, or live better. Whether that means exoskeletons, a better wheelchair, a braille display, or educational software, we want to see it.

• Or any other idea you have to hack for social change! Leverage your talent and find solutions to address technology issues facing humanity today.

Agenda:

• 6pm: Introductions, meet n greet, eat some snacks

• 6:30pm: Form teams, brainstorm and create your project proposals. See the other entries here: https://hackaday.io/submissions/prize2016/list

• 8pm: Share ideas in a round of lightning pitches and get feedback from the other teams

• 9pm: Submit your project ideas to the Hackaday Prize design challenge according to https://hackaday.io/prize/details#one

• 10pm: Wrap up and celebrate! 

~ ~ ~

What to Bring:

• Your laptop and charger

• Pen and paper

• A brain ready to generate ideas 

~ ~ ~

Parking will be available at:

https://www.google.com/maps/@30.2643693,-97.7456372,3a,75y,285.16h,80.28t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1s5_MLkpPJENl9cz9Zm87ZUg!2e0!7i13312!8i6656

<a>https://www.google.com/maps/dir//116-154+Colorado+St,+Austin,+TX+78701/@30.2642884,-97.780814,13z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m8!4m7!1m0!1m5!1m1!1s0x8644b506202a3e7f:0x2affdba1a10424be!2m2!1d-97.7457089!2d30.2642189</a>;

desc:
What does lock picking have to do with programming you may ask? O_o


Well, we discovered that lock picking brings together senior developer hacker level programmers, dev people, and newbie programmers that otherwise would not meet, in a fun, friendly, interactive, informative environment.

Thus (hobby)lock (analysis) picking free classes in partnership with the hackers of Longhorn Lockpicking is back again to provide an awesome night, with kits available to purchase!

We have a exclusive program that labels locks by levels and skillsets so you learn as you get the hang of specific picking of locks, as we relate it to code, and merrily discuss life and the universe... :-D

Will discuss code, programming, life, developing and breaking stuff, all while learning the art of feeling pins, seeing lock diagrams, and enjoying drink specials.

Afterwards around 9pm we break for secret giant burritos!

So be sure to RSVP so we know how many tables and chairs to kidnap and be sure to click the "Home" button above to check out our other upcoming events! :)

desc:
Be sure to check out our May schedule of events!

We will be having a open forum with expert Dan Frey of Estaff LLC!

Then come join us for this open forum where you get to ask what Dan believes are the hot programming languages companies ill be hiring for up to five years from now based on what they know works from years of helping programmers skip the resume and get straight to the job and getting paid!


---------------------------------------

About Dan and his staffing company:


http://nebula.wsimg.com/3d125213b41385f4563ba5bdffe9bced?AccessKeyId=B7237BDBB6DECBEEC8C2&disposition=0&alloworigin=1

With a wide variety of needs in the modern business world, Dan Frey and eStaff LLC offers several different methods to fill the empty positions of tech comapnies while helping programmers skip the resume process and get straight to the interview!

Their four methods are:

• Direct Placement - For this program, they find candidates who can join  tech companies immediately. Typically, the tech client is responsible for paying eStaff LLC so unlike other staffing agencies they do not then take from the new hire's  salary! This option is perfect for companies looking to fill a long-term position immediately and thus skip the resume process.

• Contract to Hire - This program is for the employers who want to test out candidates before hiring them. This lets you try out a potential candidate for a period of time to see if they fit well with your company. Payment for this plan is usually in the form of a bill rate of 1.4 times the hourly pay of the candidate. Contract terms are usually three or six months in length, depending on the type of position offered.

• Contract - This allows you to bring in personnel for a specific period of time. This is particularly helpful for short-term projects or initiatives where a certain expertise is needed. Maybe you just need some extra help. This is perfect for you. Payment for this plan is usually 1.4 times the hourly rate of the personnel brought in to augment the staff. These candidates may be hired directly following the completion of the contract.

• Payrolling - Do you have a potential hire that could use some experience before being brought on staff? This option is for you. Have them temporarily join the eStaff LLC team. Find out what kind of worker they are. Our staffing agency will communicate with you and help you to decide whether to hire the employee. This option is a low risk, high reward type of scenario.

Whether you’re looking to hire immediately or take time to evaluate some candidates, the strategic staffing agency here will help you to fill your employment needs nationwide including Austin and the surrounding areas. Do you need more information on one of the opportunities mentioned above?

Then come join us for this open forum where you get to ask what Dan believes are the hot programming languages companies ill be hiring for up to five years from now based on what they know works from years of helping programmers skip the resume and get straight to the job and getting paid!

Talk about code in a stress free environment, where we sell and lend tools to use with illustrations and hands on training to develop skillson numbered, leveled locks using an amazing gamification process!

Amazingly, we have discovered that the hobby of analyzing locks brings senior level developers and beginner level programmers together in a fun environment where deals and new friends are made!

Also, it helps to now have the confidence to make better, informed decisions on security systems, locks, and future modifications to your home by getting clarity on the inner working of locks, while using your hands, eyes, and ears at one time! Will be drink specials, and breaks to go out and eat giant burritoes and enjoy the good food, music, and live culture of UT campus hotspot Guadalupe st.! :)

Use the code "WEB" and it'll give your group 20% off!

Just got this now!


Texas Linux Fest is official and the schedule is live!

http://2016.texaslinuxfest.org/content/schedule

They are only honoring $20 / $50 registerations for the two days and this year appear to not have issued any promo codes that I was able to get my hands on for the group, I recommend registering just thru the $20 option and plan accordingly to the schedule on their website.

Your RSVP here, while helping me keep up with who all from this group is going, will put you on the list to receive a email alert for when our lightning talk and Youtube recording link go live.

But your rsvp will not secure your spot at Texas Linux Fest and I do not know if they are allowing $20 at the door so I highly recommend you register at the link


http://2016.texaslinuxfest.org/content/schedule

---------------------------------------------------

I appear to have been approved for Lightning talks speech on behalf of this Meetup on Saturday between 7-8pm, and they will have details there about Saturday 9pm ish after party. :)

-----------------------------------------

Hope to see yall this weekend either at this event or our Friday night 7pm meetup at Whole Foods Domain!

Thankfully this will not mess with our MEetup Friday night at the Domain as it wraps up about 5pm Friday leaving enough time to get thru rush hour traffic to the Domain by 7pm. :)

desc:
North Austin -> More details to come!


We will be having a open discussion on the pros and cons of every programming language we can cram into a intro-active two hour session!

Thereafter we will disperse to enjoy the weekend food and fun at the Domain and go out for drinks! :)

We will explore:


• Javascript - The cool kids in town or the insecure pop star waiting to happen?

• C Language - The Jedi choice for all things code or a disturbance on the force? :-/


• •Java -> Why it is so crunchy and yet the center of programming basics!

• Jquery - The rich kids accessory or the answer to a programming budget crunch?

• Python - The secret cult of programming languages or just misunderstood?

• C++ - The hipster red headed step child of programming families or the future of looking good to prospective programming jobs of the future?


• C# (Sharp) - The dark side that plot to take over the world or just the misunderstood half daughter of Microsoft?


• Objective C -  The thunder thighs with a kick language of choice for transcending humanity or just a over hyped simple code anyone can pickup on and break?

• PHP - FREEDOM, LIBERTY, and Justice language for vigilantes, or just a outdated, old past time of language codes to be shelved and forgotten?

• Ruby - Pretty, dazzling choice for the artist in mind or a flawed choice for short cuts that will lead to future compromises?

• SQL - Does it lead to all things meaningful or just a waste of time, tacos, and over rated rants?


And so much more! All programming levels welcomed and challenged with prizes thru out the night! $_$

WHY YOU SHOULD COME:

• Dan Frey has 40+ years experience in the tech industry as a teacher, mentor, hardware and software engineer, has worked with dozens of the biggest state and international tech companies

• Dan has helped over 300 programmers, developers, engineers, and even entry level students get jobs!

• Dan will share what to put on your resume and what not to put on your resume to get hired, whether its for a short term job to pay the bills, or a long term life changing career!

SUMMARY:

Come join us for this open forum where you get to ask what Dan believes are the hot programming languages companies ill be hiring for up to five years from now based on what they know works from years of helping programmers skip the resume and get straight to the job and getting paid!

---------------------------------------

About Dan and his company:

With a wide variety of needs in the modern business world, Dan Frey and eStaff LLC offers several different methods to fill the empty positions of tech companies while helping programmers skip the resume process and get straight to the interview!

Their four methods are:

• Direct Placement - For this program, they find candidates who can join  tech companies immediately. Typically, the tech client is responsible for paying eStaff LLC so unlike other staffing agencies they do not then take from the new hire's  salary! This  is perfect for companies looking to fill a long-term position immediately and thus skip the resume process.

• Contract to Hire - This program is for the employers who want to test out candidates before hiring them. This lets them try out a potential candidate for a period of time to see if they fit well with their company and the programmer / developer.

• Contract Basis - This allows Estaff to help people like you get a personnel job for a specific period of time. This is particularly helpful for short-term projects or initiatives where a certain expertise is needed. Maybe you just need some extra help getting student debt caught up part time while building up your expertise for the next big career change? ;)

• Payrolling - Helps companies take on potential hire that could use some experience before being brought on staff, aka entry level! This option is a low risk, high reward type of scenario.

Our tag team speakers - Doug and Fernando will be giving a high level overview of the Barbican Key Manager Service.  They will be introducing Barbican concepts that you'll need to know to work with Barbican effectively. 


They’ll also be covering Barbican architecture, some of the available clients that can be used to interact with Barbican, as well as give an update on ongoing integration with other services.

Doug Mendizábal is a software developer at Rackspace and the current Barbican PTL for the Mitaka cycle.

Fernando Diaz is a software developer at IBM and contributor to Barbican.

desc:
Hello everyone - Our Feb OpenStack Meetup brings us a double header session on Neutron and Project Astara! Still a hot topic in the community,  our first topic is a beginner to intermediate session discussing OpenStack Neutron and the Modular Layer 2 plugin framework and how it interacts with physical underlay. Specifically Open Networking devices. So if you are still figuring out Neutron - come on out and meetup Feb 18. Our session is being co-sponsored by Cumulus.


Speaker Bio: Kevin Witherstine is a Systems Engineer at Cumulus Networks with over 20 years of industry experience with a recent focus on SDN and virtual networking. Previous to Cumulus, Kevin has had stints with industry giants such as VMware, Cisco, and Juniper.

Our 2nd topic will provide an overview  and current state of Project Astara (formally Akanda). The Astara project aims to provide an integrated network service orchestration for connecting and security multi-tenant OpenStack environments. Astara provides deployer-configurable, multi-provider orchestration for Layer-3 through 7 network services (e.g. load balancing, routing). Our speaker is Eric Lopez,   Sr. Solution Architect, helps customers implement and integrate networking and OpenStack. Prior to Akanda/Astara, Eric joined VMware via Nicira acquisition.

Reminders:

• LOCATION - Rackspace Austin - 9001 North IH35 (east side frontage road) #150, Austin, TX 78753

• NOTE: Rackspace  security requires you provide a government issued ID in order to gain access to the facility. we recommend you arrive ~ 6:00 - 6:15pm.

• There will be a light dinner and soft drinks provided courtesy of Cumulus ~ 6:15pm - with networking time till about 6:45pm - we will kick off the speaking sessions ~ 6:45pm.
name: OpenStack Meetup - Neutron networking with Cumulus and Project Astara

desc:
UPDATE: We have added a 2nd topic to our March Meetup! Details below!

We are pleased to have Tesora CTO Amrith Kumar present an Introduction to OpenStack Trove as well as on the State of Trove. This  will include an overview of the Trove project and Database as a Service (DBaaS), explain how to interact, install and deploy different data stores, as well as detail the architecture behind how it all works.


The presentation will also cover the growth of DBaaS, why more people are turning to Trove as a solution, and share findings from Tesora’s survey on the adoption of DBaaS in the enterprise. The session will conclude with a Q&A.

Amrith Kumar brings more than two decades of experience delivering industry-leading products for companies specializing in enterprise storage applications, fault tolerant high performance systems and massively parallel databases to Tesora, which he co-founded.

Earlier, he served as vice president of technology and product management at Dataupia, maker of the Satori Data Warehousing platform, and Sepaton’s director and general manager where he was responsible for the development of the core virtual tape library product.

In our 2nd topic, PLUMgrid joins us to review containers and networking. 

It has been demonstrated that it is relatively easy to launch tens of thousands of containers on a group of hosts. But what new demands do containers at scale put on your virtual network infrastructure? Fernando Sanchez of  PLUMgrid will discuss how Neutron can provide network functionalities for containers and how and if CNI (Container Network Interface), CNM (Container Network Model) and other network models fit into OpenStack to solve the pressing security and scale requirements of containers.


Fernando Sanchez is a Principal Systems Engineeer at PLUMgrid where he works in implementing software networking infrastructures in his customer's clouds. Fernando has 15 years experience in designing, implementing and operating large-scale networks of virtually all kinds of customers ranging from tier-1 telcos to massive datacenters and enterprises.

Reminders:

• LOCATION - Rackspace Austin - 9001 North IH35 (east side frontage road) #150, Austin, TX 78753

• NOTE: Rackspace  security requires you provide a government issued ID in order to gain access to the facility. we recommend you arrive ~ 6:00 - 6:15pm.

• There will be a light dinner and soft drinks provided courtesy of Tesora ~ 6:15pm - with networking time till about 6:45pm - we will kick off the speaking sessions ~ 6:45pm.
name: OpenStack Meetup - Trove, Database as a Service, and Networking with Containers

desc:
Hello everyone - here we are post OpenStack Summit. Come on out and Meetup on OpenStack! Our May topic is sure to be intriguing > we will be reviewing new emerging performance benchmarks for cloud implementations including SPEC Cloud.


What are these tools measuring and assessing? Can the results be trusted? How are these tools developed and validated? A key consideration is the performance of Cloud services, and end-users need reliable, verifiable data in order to decide which Cloud is right for them. This session will explore the emerging SPEC Cloud standard.


Meetup and learn how performance of the cloud is measured in the SPEC Cloud tool and how cloud solutions can be optimized  to meet the conditions of the Service Level Agreements (SLA) and various performance requirements.


Also - bring your stories, impressions and feedback on the OpenStack Summit to share with the group, and we will do an open mic round table!


Speaker: Nickolas Wakou – is a Principal Performance Engineer with the Dell Cloud Solutions team. Nicholas's role, interest and activity is focused on the characterization and optimization of the performance of Cloud and Big Data solutions. Nicholas is also engages with Industry efforts to define performance benchmark specifications including SPEC Cloud committee and several committees of the TPC.

Reminders:

• LOCATION - Rackspace Austin - 9001 North IH35 (east side frontage road) #150, Austin, TX 78753

desc:
Hey everyone, our June session is brought to us by Rackspace! Come on out and Meetup on OpenStack - NOTE the NEW Monday date! 


OpenStack clouds give users to power to deploy complex servers and networks in seconds, but they can be challenging to deploy, maintain, and upgrade. The OpenStack-Ansible project allows deployers to overcome these challenges using tools that they already know.  The project is packed full of well-tested, opinionated defaults that can be reconfigured easily.  It's the backbone of Rackspace's Private Cloud product and it's the deployment mechanism for the OpenStack Innovation Center (OSIC) Cluster.


In this talk, Major Hayden will lead the audience through an overview of OpenStack-Ansible and how to use it for small and large OpenStack clouds.  The audience will learn how to perform an all-in-one deployment for testing and how to prepare multiple physical servers for an OpenStack-Ansible deployment.

Major Hayden builds OpenStack clouds as a Principal Architect at Rackspace. His primary focus is on the OpenStack-Ansible project, but he also works on information security improvements for OpenStack deployments. He is a Red Hat Certified Architect and he has contributed to several open source projects, including dracut, systemd, and Ansible. Within the Fedora Linux community, Major serves on the Fedora Security Team and Fedora Server Working Group. Major enjoys writing on his personal blog, major.io, and he talks about technical topics on Twitter as @majorhayden.

Reminders: • LOCATION - Rackspace Austin - 9001 North IH35 (east side frontage road) #150, Austin, TX 78753

• NOTE: Rackspace  security requires you provide a government issued ID in order to gain access to the facility. we recommend you arrive ~ 6:00 - 6:15pm.

• There will be a light dinner and soft drinks provided courtesy of Rackspace @6:15pm - with networking time till about 6:45pm - we will kick off the speaking sessions ~ 6:45pm.

Our session will be led by Arun Dendukuri of Cloud Evolutions.  We will start the session by covering the basics of Keystone federation, review use cases and outline the key actors in the federation mechanisms.  

We'll then review key components including SAML2 Assertion and OpenID and review configuring Keystone and Horizon for single sign-on. The session will also provide a demo of the Shibboleth plug-in and Apache configuration. 


Our speaker Arun Dendukuri is Director of Product Management with Cloud Evolutions. Arun is a lead designer, architect and developer of Private/Hybrid Clouds using OpenStack, Network and Storage designs, and integration with  AWS.
